posts.text:
If you are researching a topic begrudgingly, you are still developing yourself in the direction of that topic and thereby setting yourself up for more frustrating work in the future.

This is why it's common for people's careers to be characterized less by what they studied than by their first job.

reply_context.text:
conversely: your work determines what skills you cultivate. your skillset characterizes what future roles you might be relevant for.

Working on things that interests you ensures your skills are aligned to the kinds of work you find interesting.

posts.text: As someone who isn't attached to "publish or perish" incentives, my attitude has always been to share my ideas freely. If someone else grabs one and works on it, I haven't been "scooped": I got someone to do the work for me and I can move on to the next question faster.

reply_context.text: *within some limits, yes. But this freedom to set our own course is something we both over- and undervalue, somehow?

posts.text:
If you're confident "If I don't do this, someone else will do it!", then:

1. Your efforts aren't really growing human knowledge, you're just trying to be first.
2. You'll have tunnel vision on competitive/crowded research agendas.

If you care about novelty or WLB: do stuff other people aren't.

reply_context.text:
Something worrying me: many seem to change their research direction out of FOMO, reacting to (the obvious) recent trend: "If I don't do this, someone else will do it!"

One of the key perks we have in academia is the freedom to set our own agenda.* If someone else canâ€”and WILLâ€”do it, why would you?

You donâ€™t need a violent coup or a hacked voting machines to overthrow democracy.
